Message.Title: Looks Set to Double in Value Next Week - Must Read!
Message.Msg: Concurrent (CCUR) looks ready to double in value next week currently $7.76 only has 9.2mm o/s with $24.6mm in cash no debt enterprise value of only $46.79mm or 0.75x revenue of $62.59mm. CCUR has the lowest multiple in the industry when its gross margins of 58% are the second highest. Seachange (SEAC) along with CCUR are the two leading video on demand (VOD) companies and together they control the global VOD market with a combined market share of over 50%. SEAC has lower gross margins of 50% yet it's trading with enterprise value/revenue ratio of 1.9, which would value CCUR at $15.60 per share. SEAC is a money losing company while CCUR's net income has been exploding! CCUR's EPS last quarter was double the quarter before and quadruple two quarters ago. Virgin Media (VMED) just chose CCUR's multi-screen video delivery platform MediaHawk over SEAC's platform. SEAC was providing traditional VOD services to VMED so for VMED to choose CCUR for their new Virgin TV Anywhere platform is HUGE. There is a good chance CCUR will replace SEAC's software for traditional VOD at VMED before long as well! VMED is the #1 largest cable TV company in the UK with 3.8 million subscribers! CCUR also just announced the signing of an undisclosed Top 5 North American pay-TV company! Together these two major new clients could potentially allow CCUR's EPS to once again double, triple, or quadruple over the next 2-3 quarters! Major consolidation is taking place in this space and CCUR and SEAC have been rumored takeover targets, Google it to see for yourself! If neither of them get boughtout, SEAC has enough cash to acquire CCUR for a huge premium of $12 per share and it would still be very accretive to their earnings! CCUR has the best looking chart in the market today and looks ready to absolutely explode today!

Love the reoccuring revenue stream from each Grid GPU every year. And of course --- Share buybacks and they are happening. Most companies buy at the top with a few exception....Nvidia is buying at the bottom Then some Tegra 4 action sometime in couple of months, and the big question mark "Project Shield". The Tech Press will have a field day but Nvidia will make money on each and every one. Nvidia is paying us a dividend to wait....Enjoy the Dividend. Sells some calls if you like. Spring is here.
Just another drive-by idiot.
1 post | Last Activity: 1 hour 24 minutes ago Member since: Mar 22, 2013. A reincarnated short at that...LOL

Even though Nvidia's performance on a yearly basis is slightly higher than I expected, there was a decrease of 8% in quarterly performance, which was due to weaker Tegra sales (even though there was a transition from Tegra 3 to Tegra 4) and a drop in desktop GPU sales. Additionally, increases in operating expenses have outnumbered the revenue. This trend isn't expected to reverse in near future. In comparison to competitors QCOM (NASDAQ: QCOM) and AMD (NYSE: AMD) Nvidia's performance is not up to the mark. Its lack of smartphone penetration isn't going to pick up in the coming future as Tegra 4 faces intense competition, and vertical integration by OEM handsets will further worsen the situation. Hence, future revenue, which is primarily based on Tegra, may not increase as expected. High dependence on HTC, which itself is losing market share, adds additional negativity to Nvidia's performance. Recently, Nvidia's loss of the Google nexus platform to QCOM, plus poor performance of Microsoft Surface tablet sales, makes Nvidia a less lucrative stock. I expect that economic scenario will further worsen, making competition more aggressive. If the economic scenario deteriorates, this will further reduce consumer demand for PCs. The PC market generates about 80% of Nvidia’s revenue. This high dependence on a particular segment, i.e. PC sales, will make Nvidia a highly volatile stock. There are greener pastures elsewhere. This is a deadman walking stock.

Interesting spin... " weaker Tegra sales (even though there was a transition from Tegra 3 to Tegra 4)" what transition ?? where is it ?? "lack of smartphone penetration isn't going to pick up" NVidia just announced their first part targeted at smartphones... you know that, but are too busy spinning... " increases in operating expenses have outnumbered the revenue." you're too busy spinning to notice all the new products... but even you will see obvious with the transition from Tegra 3 to Tegra 4 "Nvidia a highly volatile stock." Message.Title: Nvidia's automotive Tegra chips use a special TSMC flow
Message.Msg: Says it has exclusive intellectual property SAN JOSE: CHIP DESIGNER Nvidia said at its GPU Technology Conference (GTC) that it has exclusive intellectual property (IP) with TSMC in the fabrication of its Tegra automotive chips. Nvidia has shipped around 2.5 million Tegra chips into the automotive industry, with firms such as Audi, BMW, Lamborghini and Tesla using a mixture of Tegra 2 and Tegra 3 chips. Philip Hughes, director of Automotive sales and business development at Nvidia told The INQUIRER that the Tegra chips that end up in cars are fabbed using a specific "automotive flow' at TSMC. Hughes said that while the Tegra 3 chip in the Tesla has the same architecture as the chip that powers Google's Nexus 7 tablet, it is fabbed using a different process flow that is specific to chips intended for the automotive industry. By different flow, Hughes was referring to additional steps to ensure validation and reliability rather than a different chip geometry. Hughes added that Nvidia worked with TSMC to develop the automative flow, adding that there is Nvidia specific IP in that flow. So while TSMC has other customers that use it for producing chips for the automotive industry, it cannot take advantage of Nvidia's proprietary process features. Nvidia has enjoyed considerable success in the automotive industry given its relativley recent entrance into what is a very conservative market. Hughes said that the firm already has orders for a further 20 million Tegra chips from car makers, which is impressive given that its chips have typically ended up in high-end motorcars. Given that Nvidia has gone to the effort of working with TSMC to customise its process flow, it is safe to say the company is very serious about breaking into the automotive industry, an industry that many semiconductor vendors increasingly see as an industry that will drive revenue as PC sales decrease.

Message.Title: GE! Bet you didn't see this one coming.
Message.Msg: GE puts new Nvidia tech through its paces, ponders HPC future From register story. Hybrid CPU-GPU chips plus RDMA and PCI-Express make for screamin' iron By Timothy Prickett Morgan • Get more from this author Posted in HPC , 22nd March 2013 16:27 GMT Free whitepaper – EMA advanced performance analytics report GTC 2013 A top General Electric techie gave a presentation at the GPU Technology Conference this week in San José, California, and discussed the benefits of Remote Direct Memory Access (RDMA) for InfiniBand and its companion GPUDirect method of linking GPU memories to each other across InfiniBand networks. And just for fun, the GE tech also specced out how he would go about building supercomputers using Nvidia's future hybrid CPU-GPU chips based on the "Project Denver" cores that Nvidia has been working on for the past several years. Don't be at all surprised that GE is fiddling about with Nvidia chippery. The company does a lot of different things, and one of them is make military-specification computing and visualization systems for fighter jets, tanks, drones, and other weapons systems. Given the nature of the systems it creates, GE has become an expert in chips and network-lashing technologies, particularly given the real-time nature of the data gathering and processing that military systems require. The GE techie who spoke at Nvidia's event was Dusty Franklin, GPGPU applications engineer at GE's Intelligent Platforms division, and Nvidia introduced his session at the conference saying he was one of the world's experts on RDMA and GPUDirect.

Topic.Title: The One Bad Thing About Nvidia's New Business This Year

Message.Msg: "If the business unit does well, NVIdia themselves will break it out for everyone to see... Money is sexier to investors than gaming.." As long as the bottom line is better all is better. If not it's just a note for the analysts, with more wait and see from them. The reason for combining PSB and GPU into one reporting segment was to refocus analysts and media perceptions away from the silly notion that Integrated Graphics are killing Nvidia's businesses. Doubt they will open it up to show by segment for a year or so. But Cloud Gaming could really get a buzz under the stock if it really takes off. WS loves stories. Don't get me wrong Nvidia Grid will be a good business.

Topic.Title: ARM to help second-tier IC designers to catch up, DigiTimes reports

Message.Msg: How much does Tegra add to Nvidia's bottom line? Can Nvidia cut the price of the Tegra and still make a profit? More China smartphone vendors adopt MediaTek quad-core solutions Cage Chao, Taipei; Steve Shen, DIGITIMES [Wednesday 20 March 2013] Following the steps of Lenovo and Coolpad, two other China-based smartphone vendors, Huawei and ZTE, reportedly will also adopt MediaTek's quad-core MT6589 solutions for the production of their high-end smartphones – a move which will further enhance MediaTek's leading market position in China's smartphone solution segment, according to industry sources. With orders from Lenovo, Coolpad, Huawei and ZTE, MediaTek is expected to increase its previous goal of shipping over 200 million smartphone solutions in 2013, said the sources. The adoption of MediaTek's quad-core solutions by Huawei and ZTE comes only one month after the two vendors highlighted their latest high-end smartphone models powered by Qualcomm's solutions at the recently concluded Mobile World Congress (MWC) 2013, the sources noted. But Huawei and ZTE are being forced to use MediaTek's solutions due to increasing price competition in China's high-end smartphone segment, said the sources, adding that prices of high-profile smartphones in China have dropped to CNY1,200-1800 (US$193-289) recently. Huawei and ZTE are expected to launch smartphones powered by MediaTek's quad-core solutions in the second half of 2013, the sources noted.

One thing to be said of Nvidia's new VCA - Grid - Server Blades - whatever they call it - how often do you hear of IBM adopting somebody else product into their Enterprise offerings. This is a company so totally self sufficient that it's extremely rare - unless it is a BIG DEAL and they don't have an alternative. IBM is the KING of enterprise hardware and software solutions - often building everything themselves!
